bioghist.p: Chester Garfield Fuson (1881-1965) was born in Wakeeney, Kansas. He graduated from college with a degree in education. He married Phebe Meeker in December 1909. Prior to getting married, Fuson taught education and geography at the Canton Christian College in Canton, China, and assisted Don Sowers, a scientist who conducted a magnetic survey across Asia. After their marriage, the Fusons returned to China, and Chester returned to his position at Canton Christian College. The Fusons became teaching missionaries in 1917 under the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, and continued their work until 1949. They had three sons, Ben, Nelson, and William.

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the collection pertains to Fuson's participation in the magnetic survey across Asia. Materials include: an original and copy of Fuson's diary of a nine month trip from Peking to Bombay in 1909 and other documentation related to the trip; several reports prepared for possible publication, including "The Old Asian Trail," "Through Chinese Turkestan," and "The Five Great Passes of the Karakorum Route"; the annual report of the Department of Terrestrial Magnetism of the Carnegie Institution of Washington from 1909 which includes a report of the trip; magazine articles from the 1940s and 1960s on Central Asia; photographs taken by Fuson on the trip; a book and reprints of articles by Chester Fuson; and an oversize map of China.
